answers.answer: Hi,How are you?I can understand your worry and concern, but please relax. The white matter changes seen on MRI can be due to stroke, chronic headache, old age, high BP, diabetes, Alzheimer’s, chronic alcoholism, Multiple sclerosis, and migraine.As of now it seems that the white matter changes in your case can be due to migraine, if other causes like alcoholism, diabetes and high BP can be excluded.Usually follow up is done after 6 months to rule out Alzheimers and MS.Membrane thickening of the left maxillary sinus does indicate a sinus infection or an allergy and since your headaches are also on the left side, this may be the cause of your headaches. Please consult your PCP about it as you may need medications to clear the infection.Take care!

question: Hi, I have a history of people suffering from migraines in my family.  As a teenager, I also suffered from them and was on a preventitive medication through high school.  When I went off to college, I seemed to only suffer an occassional headache but now that I am 33, it seems that they have returned.  I have been treated for the past 10 months for migraines, and on Topomax and it doesn't seem to help a lot.  I have had a CT scan and my doctor said it came back fine, just recently had an MRI of the brain, with and without contrast and that is what has concerned me.  My doctor said it showed vascular scarring and I need a follow up in 6 months.  No big deal.  But when I requested a copy of the report and read it at home, nothing was mentioned about vascular scarring?  My daily headache/pain is always limited to the left side of my head.  The pain I experience does not seem to follow any triggers, weather, foods... nothing.  And rarely pain killers that I take will help ease it so I can cope.  I am concerned it is more than migraines because the MRI speaks to the"nonenhancing increased T2-weighted signal in the white matter laterally adjacent to the atrium of the left lateral ventricle".  I have seen the pictures and the white matter.  What is this and why didn't my doctor speak to this when going over the report with me?  Another finding in the report was "minimal membrane thickening of the left maxillary sinus".  Is this the start of a sinus infection, should I see my PCP for treatment?  I am just concerned that I wasn't given clarity form my doctor on what the findings were in my MRI, should I get a 2nd opinion?  Nowhere did it say anything about scarring?  It also references the T2-weighted matter as a nonspecific finding.  What does that mean?  It goes on to say "A more aggressive lesion is considered less likely."  Is the white matter a lesion?  There are no measurements of this matter.  Just worried....and need answers?
title: 2nd opinion needed?
